member.name: T:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI
member.summary: Provides declarations for the GDI API Calls

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.GetBitmapBits(System.IntPtr,System.Int64,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Copies the Contents of a Bitmap to a buffer

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.DeleteObject(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Deletes a GDI object
member.returns: True if succeeded.

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.SelectObject(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Selects a GDI object into memory
member.param: Device context to insert the object
member.returns: Handle to the object being replaced if succeeds.

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.CreateCompatibleDC(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates a compatible device context
member.param: Device context to be compatible to
member.returns: A device context

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.BitBlt(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,Win32.GDI.RasterOperation)
member.summary: Copies a region from a device context into another
member.returns: True if succeeded.

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.CreateDC(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates a device context
member.returns: A device context

member.name: M:Win32.GDI.GDIAPI.DeleteDC(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Deletes a device context
member.returns: True if succeeded

member.name: T:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation
member.summary: Specifies a raster-operation code. These codes define how the color data for the source rectangle is to be combined with the color data for the destination rectangle to achieve the final color.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.Blackness
member.summary: Fills the destination rectangle using the color associated with index 0 in the physical palette. (This color is black for the default physical palette.)

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.CaptureBlit
member.summary: Windows 98/Me, Windows 2000/XP: Includes any windows that are layered on top of your window in the resulting image. By default, the image only contains your window. Note that this generally cannot be used for printing device contexts.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.DestinationInvert
member.summary: Inverts the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.MergeCopy
member.summary: Merges the colors of the source rectangle with the brush currently selected in hdcDest, by using the Boolean AND operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.MergePaint
member.summary: Merges the colors of the inverted source rectangle with the colors of the destination rectangle by using the Boolean OR operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.NoMirrorBitmap
member.summary: Windows 98/Me, Windows 2000/XP: Prevents the bitmap from being mirrored.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.NotSourceCopy
member.summary: Copies the inverted source rectangle to the destination.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.NotSourceErase
member.summary: Combines the colors of the source and destination rectangles by using the Boolean OR operator and then inverts the resultant color.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.PatternCopy
member.summary: Copies the brush currently selected in hdcDest, into the destination bitmap.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.PatternInvert
member.summary: Combines the colors of the brush currently selected in hdcDest, with the colors of the destination rectangle by using the Boolean XOR operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.PatternPaint
member.summary: Combines the colors of the brush currently selected in hdcDest, with the colors of the inverted source rectangle by using the Boolean OR operator. The result of this operation is combined with the colors of the destination rectangle by using the Boolean OR operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.SourceAnd
member.summary: Combines the colors of the source and destination rectangles by using the Boolean AND operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.SourceCopy
member.summary: Copies the source rectangle directly to the destination rectangle.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.SourceErase
member.summary: Combines the inverted colors of the destination rectangle with the colors of the source rectangle by using the Boolean AND operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.SourceInvert
member.summary: Combines the colors of the source and destination rectangles by using the Boolean XOR operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.SourcePaint
member.summary: Combines the colors of the source and destination rectangles by using the Boolean OR operator.

member.name: F:Win32.GDI.RasterOperation.Whiteness
member.summary: Fills the destination rectangle using the color associated with index 1 in the physical palette. (This color is white for the default physical palette.)

member.name: T:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess
member.summary: The valid access rights for process objects include the DELETE, READ_CONTROL, SYNCHRONIZE, WRITE_DAC, and WRITE_OWNER standard access rights, in addition to the following process-specific access rights.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.AllAccess
member.summary: All possible access rights for a process object.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.CreateProcess
member.summary: Required to create a process.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.CreateThread
member.summary: Required to create a thread.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.DuplicateHandle
member.summary: Required to duplicate a handle using DuplicateHandle.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.QueryInformation
member.summary: Required to retrieve certain information about a process, such as its token, exit code, and priority class (see OpenProcessToken, GetExitCodeProcess, GetPriorityClass, and IsProcessInJob).

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.SetQuota
member.summary: Required to set memory limits using SetProcessWorkingSetSize.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.SetInformation
member.summary: Required to set certain information about a process, such as its priority class (see SetPriorityClass).

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.Terminate
member.summary: Required to terminate a process using TerminateProcess.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.VMOperation
member.summary: Required to perform an operation on the address space of a process (see VirtualProtectEx and WriteProcessMemory).

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.VMRead
member.summary: Required to read memory in a process using ReadProcessMemory.

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess.VMWrite
member.summary: Required to write to memory in a process using WriteProcessMemory. SYNCHRONIZE Required to wait for the process to terminate using the wait functions.

member.name: T:Win32.Kernel32.DriveType
member.summary: Types of logical drives

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DriveType.CD
member.summary: CD-ROM

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DriveType.Fixed
member.summary: Fixed Disk

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DriveType.Removable
member.summary: Removable Disk

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DriveType.Remote
member.summary: Remote Disk

member.name: F:Win32.Kernel32.DriveType.RamDisk
member.summary: Ram Disk

member.name: T:Win32.Kernel32.Kernel32API
member.summary: Summary description for Kernel32API.

member.name: M:Win32.Kernel32.Kernel32API.GetDriveType(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the media type of a logical drive
member.returns: Returns the media type of a logical drive

member.name: M:Win32.Kernel32.Kernel32API.OpenProcess(Win32.Kernel32.DesiredAccess,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: The OpenProcess function opens an existing process object.
member.param: Access to the process object. This access right is checked against any security descriptor for the process. This parameter can be one or more of the process access rights.
If this parameter is TRUE, the handle is inheritable. If the parameter is FALSE, the handle cannot be inherited.
Identifier of the process to open.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is an open handle to the specified process. If the function fails, the return value is NULL

member.name: M:Win32.Kernel32.Kernel32API.CloseHandle(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The CloseHandle function closes an open object handle.
member.param: Handle to an open object. This parameter can be a pseudo handle or INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero.

member.name: T:Win32.PSAPI.PSAPI
member.summary: Summary description for PSAPI.

member.name: M:Win32.PSAPI.PSAPI.EnumProcessModules(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr@,System.UInt32,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: The EnumProcessModules function retrieves a handle for each module in the specified process.
member.param: Pointer to the array that receives the list of module handles.
Size of the lphModule array, in bytes.
Number of bytes required to store all module handles in the lphModule array.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:Win32.PSAPI.PSAPI.GetModuleFileNameExW(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.UInt32)
member.summary: The GetModuleFileNameEx function retrieves the fully-qualified path for the file containing the specified module.
member.param: Handle to the process that contains the module. The handle must have the PROCESS_QUERY_INFORMATION and PROCESS_VM_READ access rights. For more information, see Process Security and Access Rights.
Handle to the module. If this parameter is NULL, GetModuleFileNameEx returns the path of the executable file of the process specified in hProcess.

Pointer to the null-terminated buffer that receives the fully-qualified path to the module. If the size of the file name is larger than the value of the nSize parameter, the file name is truncated and null terminated.
Size of the lpFilename buffer, in characters.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value specifies the length of the string copied to the buffer. If the function fails, the return value is zero.

member.name: T:Win32.Shell32.Shell32API
member.summary: Summary description for Shell32API.

member.name: M:Win32.Shell32.Shell32API.ShellExecuteEx(Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo)
member.summary: Executes an action with a file
member.param: Information on how to execute the file
member.returns: True if succeeded. False if not

member.name: M:Win32.Shell32.Shell32API.SHGetFileInfo(System.String,System.UInt32,Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo@,System.UInt32,Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags)
member.summary: Gets information on a file
member.param: The SHFileInfo structure to receive the information
Size of the structured indicated in psfi
Flags to indicate what file information to receive
member.returns: 0 if fails. Otherwise either succeeded and optionally the EXE type.

member.name: T:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo
member.summary: Contains information used by ShellExecuteEx.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.cbSize
member.summary: Size of the structure, in bytes.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.fMask
member.summary: Array of flags that indicate the content and validity of the other structure members. This can be a combination of the following values.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.hwnd
member.summary: Window handle to any message boxes that the system might produce while executing this function.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.lpVerb
member.summary:
String, referred to as a verb, that specifies the action to be performed. The set of available verbs depends on the particular file or folder. Generally, the actions available from an object's shortcut menu are available verbs. For more specific information about verbs, see Object Verbs. For further discussion of shortcut menus, see Extending Shortcut Menus. If you set this parameter to NULL:
* For systems prior to Windows 2000, the default verb is used if it is valid and available in the registry. If not, the "open" verb is used. * For Windows 2000 and later systems, the default verb is used if available. If not, the "open" verb is used. If neither verb is available, the system uses the first verb listed in the registry.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.lpFile
member.summary:
Address of a null-terminated string that specifies the name of the file or object on which ShellExecuteEx will perform the action specified by the lpVerb parameter. The system registry verbs that are supported by the ShellExecuteEx function include "open" for executable files and document files and "print" for document files for which a print handler has been registered. Other applications might have added Shell verbs through the system registry, such as "play" for .avi and .wav files. To specify a Shell namespace object, pass the fully qualified parse name and set the SEE_MASK_INVOKEIDLIST flag in the fMask parameter.
Note If the SEE_MASK_INVOKEIDLIST flag is set, you can use either lpFile or lpIDList to identify the item by its file system path or its PIDL respectively. Note If the path is not included with the name, the current directory is assumed.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.lpParameters
member.summary: Address of a null-terminated string that contains the application parameters. The parameters must be separated by spaces. If the lpFile member specifies a document file, lpParameters should be NULL.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.lpDirectory
member.summary: Address of a null-terminated string that specifies the name of the working directory. If this member is not specified, the current directory is used as the working directory.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.nShow
member.summary: Flags that specify how an application is to be shown when it is opened. It can be one of the SW_ values listed for the ShellExecute function. If lpFile specifies a document file, the flag is simply passed to the associated application. It is up to the application to decide how to handle it.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.hInstApp
member.summary: If the function succeeds, it sets this member to a value greater than 32. If the function fails, it is set to an SE_ERR_XXX error value that indicates the cause of the failure. Although hInstApp is declared as an HINSTANCE for compatibility with 16-bit Windows applications, it is not a true HINSTANCE. It can be cast only to an int and compared to either 32 or the following SE_ERR_XXX error codes.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.lpIDList
member.summary: Address of an ITEMIDLIST structure to contain an item identifier list uniquely identifying the file to execute. This member is ignored if the fMask member does not include SEE_MASK_IDLIST or SEE_MASK_INVOKEIDLIST.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.lpClass
member.summary: Address of a null-terminated string that specifies the name of a file class or a globally unique identifier (GUID). This member is ignored if fMask does not include SEE_MASK_CLASSNAME.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.hkeyClass
member.summary: Handle to the registry key for the file class. This member is ignored if fMask does not include SEE_MASK_CLASSKEY.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.dwHotKey
member.summary: Hot key to associate with the application. The low-order word is the virtual key code, and the high-order word is a modifier flag (HOTKEYF_). For a list of modifier flags, see the description of the WM_SETHOTKEY message. This member is ignored if fMask does not include SEE_MASK_HOTKEY.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.hIcon
member.summary: Handle to the icon for the file class. This member is ignored if fMask does not include SEE_MASK_ICON.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellExecuteInfo.hProcess
member.summary:
Handle to the newly started application. This member is set on return and is always NULL unless fMask is set to SEE_MASK_NOCLOSEPROCESS. Even if fMask is set to SEE_MASK_NOCLOSEPROCESS, hProcess will be NULL if no process was launched. For example, if a document to be launched is a URL and an instance of Microsoft Internet Explorer is already running, it will display the document. No new process is launched, and hProcess will be NULL.
Note ShellExecuteEx does not always return an hProcess, even if a process is launched as the result of the call. For example, an hProcess does not return when you use SEE_MASK_INVOKEIDLIST to invoke IContextMenu.

member.name: T:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags
member.summary: Summary description for ShellGetFileInfoFlags.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.AddOverlays
member.summary: Version 5.0. Apply the appropriate overlays to the file's icon. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.SpecifiedAttributes
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ATTRIBUTES to indicate that the dwAttributes member of the SHFILEINFO structure at psfi contains the specific attributes that are desired. These attributes are passed to IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf. If this flag is not specified, 0xFFFFFFFF is passed to IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf, requesting all attributes. This flag cannot be specified with the SHGFI_ICON flag.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.Attributes
member.summary: Retrieve the item attributes. The attributes are copied to the dwAttributes member of the structure specified in the psfi parameter. These are the same attributes that are obtained from IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.DisplayName
member.summary: Retrieve the display name for the file. The name is copied to the szDisplayName member of the structure specified in psfi. The returned display name uses the long file name, if there is one, rather than the 8.3 form of the file name.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.EXEType
member.summary: Retrieve the type of the executable file if pszPath identifies an executable file. The information is packed into the return value. This flag cannot be specified with any other flags.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.Icon
member.summary: Retrieve the handle to the icon that represents the file and the index of the icon within the system image list. The handle is copied to the hIcon member of the structure specified by psfi, and the index is copied to the iIcon member.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.IconLocation
member.summary: Retrieve the name of the file that contains the icon representing the file specified by pszPath, as returned by the IExtractIcon::GetIconLocation method of the file's icon handler. Also retrieve the icon index within that file. The name of the file containing the icon is copied to the szDisplayName member of the structure specified by psfi. The icon's index is copied to that structure's iIcon member.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.LargeIcon
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve the file's large icon. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.AddLinkOverlay
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to add the link overlay to the file's icon. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.OpenIcon
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve the file's open icon. Also used to modify SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX, causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains the file's small open icon. A container object displays an open icon to indicate that the container is open. The SHGFI_ICON and/or SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.OverlayIndex
member.summary: Version 5.0. Return the index of the overlay icon. The value of the overlay index is returned in the upper eight bits of the iIcon member of the structure specified by psfi.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.PathIsItemIDList
member.summary: Indicate that pszPath is the address of an ITEMIDLIST structure rather than a path name.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.SelectedIcon
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to blend the file's icon with the system highlight color. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.ShellIconSize
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve a Shell-sized icon. If this flag is not specified the function sizes the icon according to the system metric values. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.SmallIcon
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve the file's small icon. Also used to modify SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX, causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains small icon images. The SHGFI_ICON and/or SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX flag must also be set.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.SystemImageListIconIndex
member.summary: Retrieve the index of a system image list icon. If successful, the index is copied to the iIcon member of psfi. The return value is a handle to the system image list. Only those images whose indices are successfully copied to iIcon are valid. Attempting to access other images in the system image list will result in undefined behavior.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.FileTypeName
member.summary: Retrieve the string that describes the file's type. The string is copied to the szTypeName member of the structure specified in psfi.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.ShellGetFileInfoFlags.UseFileAttributes
member.summary: Indicates that the function should not attempt to access the file specified by pszPath. Rather, it should act as if the file specified by pszPath exists with the file attributes passed in dwFileAttributes. This flag cannot be combined with the SHGFI_ATTRIBUTES, SHGFI_EXETYPE, or SHGFI_PIDL flags.

member.name: T:Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo
member.summary: Contains information about a file object.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo.hIcon
member.summary: Handle to the icon that represents the file. You are responsible for destroying this handle with DestroyIcon when you no longer need it.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo.iIcon
member.summary: Index of the icon image within the system image list.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo.dwAttributes
member.summary: Array of values that indicates the attributes of the file object. For information about these values, see the IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf method.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo.szDisplayName
member.summary: String that contains the name of the file as it appears in the Microsoft Windows Shell, or the path and file name of the file that contains the icon representing the file.

member.name: F:Win32.Shell32.SHFileInfo.szTypeName
member.summary: String that describes the type of file.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.AlphaFormat
member.summary: Controls the way the source and destination bitmaps are interpreted.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.AlphaFormat.SourceAlpha
member.summary: This flag is set when the bitmap has an Alpha channel (that is, per-pixel alpha). Note that the APIs use premultiplied alpha, which means that the red, green and blue channel values in the bitmap must be premultiplied with the alpha channel value. For example, if the alpha channel value is x, the red, green and blue channels must be multiplied by x and divided by 0xff prior to the call.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.BlendFunction
member.summary: Represents the Win32 BLENDFUNCTION structure which controls blending by specifying the blending functions for source and destination bitmaps.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.BlendFunction.BlendOp
member.summary: Specifies the source blend operation. Currently, the only source and destination blend operation that has been defined is AC_SRC_OVER. For details, see the following Remarks section.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.BlendFunction.BlendFlags
member.summary: Must be zero.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.BlendFunction.SourceConstantAlpha
member.summary: Specifies an alpha transparency value to be used on the entire source bitmap. The SourceConstantAlpha value is combined with any per-pixel alpha values in the source bitmap. If you set SourceConstantAlpha to 0, it is assumed that your image is transparent. Set the SourceConstantAlpha value to 255 (opaque) when you only want to use per-pixel alpha values.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.BlendFunction.AlphaFormat
member.summary: This member controls the way the source and destination bitmaps are interpreted. AlphaFormat has the following value.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.BlendOperation
member.summary: Specifies the source blend operation.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.BlendOperation.SourceOver
member.summary: The source bitmap is placed over the destination bitmap based on the alpha values of the source pixels.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues
member.summary: Specifies the 32-bit value to retrieve. To retrieve a 32-bit value from the extra class memory, specify the positive, zero-based byte offset of the value to be retrieved. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra class memory, minus four; for example, if you specified 12 or more bytes of extra class memory, a value of 8 would be an index to the third 32-bit integer. To retrieve any other value from the WNDCLASSEX structure, specify one of the following values.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.Atom
member.summary: Retrieves an ATOM value that uniquely identifies the window class. This is the same atom that the RegisterClassEx function returns.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.ExtraClassMemory
member.summary: Retrieves the size, in bytes, of the extra memory associated with the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.ExtraWindowMemory
member.summary: Retrieves the size, in bytes, of the extra window memory associated with each window in the class. For information on how to access this memory, see GetWindowLong.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.BackgroundBrush
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the background brush associated with the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.Cursor
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the cursor associated with the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.LargeIcon
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the icon associated with the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.SmallIcon
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the small icon associated with the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.RegistrantModule
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the module that registered the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.MenuName
member.summary: Retrieves the address of the menu name string. The string identifies the menu resource associated with the class.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.Style
member.summary: Retrieves the window-class style bits.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.ClassLongValues.WindowProcedure
member.summary: Retrieves the address of the window procedure, or a handle representing the address of the window procedure. You must use the CallWindowProc function to call the window procedure.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.EnumWindowsProc
member.summary: The EnumWindowsProc function is an application-defined callback function used with the EnumWindows or EnumDesktopWindows function. It receives top-level window handles. The WNDENUMPROC type defines a pointer to this callback function. EnumWindowsProc is a placeholder for the application-defined function name.
member.param: Specifies the application-defined value given in EnumWindows or EnumDesktopWindows.
member.returns: To continue enumeration, the callback function must return TRUE; to stop enumeration, it must return FALSE.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand
member.summary: Specifies the relationship between the specified window and the window whose handle is to be retrieved. This parameter can be one of the following values.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.Child
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the child window at the top of the Z order, if the specified window is a parent window; otherwise, the retrieved handle is NULL. The function examines only child windows of the specified window. It does not examine descendant windows.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.First
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is highest in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies the topmost window that is highest in the Z order. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies the top-level window that is highest in the Z order. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies the sibling window that is highest in the Z order.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.Last
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is lowest in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies the topmost window that is lowest in the Z order. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies the top-level window that is lowest in the Z order. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies the sibling window that is lowest in the Z order.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.Next
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window below the specified window in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies the topmost window below the specified window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies the top-level window below the specified window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies the sibling window below the specified window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.Previous
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window above the specified window in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies the topmost window above the specified window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies the top-level window above the specified window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies the sibling window above the specified window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.EnabledPopUp
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: The retrieved handle identifies the enabled popup window owned by the specified window (the search uses the first such window found using GW_HWNDNEXT); otherwise, if there are no enabled popup windows, the retrieved handle is that of the specified window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.GetWindowCommand.Owner
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the specified window's owner window, if any.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.HookProc
member.summary: Delegate for the hook process

member.name: T:Win32.User32.HookType
member.summary: Specifies the type of hook procedure to be installed. This parameter can be one of the following values.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_CALLWNDPROC
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors messages before the system sends them to the destination window procedure. For more information, see the CallWndProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_CALLWNDPROCRET
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors messages after they have been processed by the destination window procedure. For more information, see the CallWndRetProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_CBT
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that receives notifications useful to a computer-based training (CBT) application. For more information, see the CBTProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_DEBUG
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure useful for debugging other hook procedures. For more information, see the DebugProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_FOREGROUNDIDLE
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that will be called when the application's foreground thread is about to become idle. This hook is useful for performing low priority tasks during idle time. For more information, see the ForegroundIdleProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_GETMESSAGE
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors messages posted to a message queue. For more information, see the GetMsgProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_JOURNALPLAYBACK
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that posts messages previously recorded by a WH_JOURNALRECORD hook procedure. For more information, see the JournalPlaybackProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_JOURNALRECORD
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that records input messages posted to the system message queue. This hook is useful for recording macros. For more information, see the JournalRecordProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_KEYBOARD
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors keystroke messages. For more information, see the KeyboardProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_KEYBOARD_LL
member.summary: Windows NT/2000/XP: Installs a hook procedure that monitors low-level keyboard input events. For more information, see the LowLevelKeyboardProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_MOUSE
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors mouse messages. For more information, see the MouseProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_MOUSE_LL
member.summary: Windows NT/2000/XP: Installs a hook procedure that monitors low-level mouse input events. For more information, see the LowLevelMouseProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_MSGFILTER
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors messages generated as a result of an input event in a dialog box, message box, menu, or scroll bar. For more information, see the MessageProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_SHELL
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that receives notifications useful to shell applications. For more information, see the ShellProc hook procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookType.WH_SYSMSGFILTER
member.summary: Installs a hook procedure that monitors messages generated as a result of an input event in a dialog box, message box, menu, or scroll bar. The hook procedure monitors these messages for all applications in the same desktop as the calling thread. For more information, see the SysMsgProc hook procedure.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage
member.summary: Specifies the identifier of the mouse message.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_LBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: Left mouse button down

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_LBUTTONUP
member.summary: Left mouse button up

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_MOUSEMOVE
member.summary: Mouse move

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_MOUSEWHEEL
member.summary: Mouse wheel scroll

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_RBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: Right mouse button down

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_RBUTTONUP
member.summary: Right mouse button up

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_MBUTTONDOWN
member.summary: Middle mouse button down

member.name: F:Win32.User32.HookWindowMessage.WM_MBUTTONUP
member.summary: Middle mouse button up

member.name: T:Win32.User32.IconInformation
member.summary: Represents the Win32 ICONINFO structure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.IconInformation.fIcon
member.summary: Specifies whether this structure defines an icon or a cursor. A value of TRUE specifies an icon; FALSE specifies a cursor.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.IconInformation.xHotspot
member.summary: Specifies the x-coordinate of a cursor's hot spot. If this structure defines an icon, the hot spot is always in the center of the icon, and this member is ignored.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.IconInformation.yHotspot
member.summary: Specifies the y-coordinate of the cursor's hot spot. If this structure defines an icon, the hot spot is always in the center of the icon, and this member is ignored.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.IconInformation.hbmMask
member.summary: Specifies the icon bitmask bitmap. If this structure defines a black and white icon, this bitmask is formatted so that the upper half is the icon AND bitmask and the lower half is the icon XOR bitmask. Under this condition, the height should be an even multiple of two. If this structure defines a color icon, this mask only defines the AND bitmask of the icon.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.IconInformation.hbmColor
member.summary: Handle to the icon color bitmap. This member can be optional if this structure defines a black and white icon. The AND bitmask of hbmMask is applied with the SRCAND flag to the destination; subsequently, the color bitmap is applied (using XOR) to the destination by using the SRCINVERT flag.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.KeyModifiers
member.summary: Specifies keys that must be pressed in combination with the key specified.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.KeyModifiers.None
member.summary: No Key.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.KeyModifiers.Alt
member.summary: Either ALT key must be held down.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.KeyModifiers.Control
member.summary: Either CTRL key must be held down.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.KeyModifiers.Shift
member.summary: Either SHIFT key must be held down.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.KeyModifiers.Windows
member.summary: Either WINDOWS key was held down. These keys are labeled with the Microsoft Windows logo.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.MouseHookStruct
member.summary: The MOUSEHOOKSTRUCT structure contains information about a mouse event passed to a WH_MOUSE hook procedure, MouseProc.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.MouseHookStruct.pt
member.summary: Specifies a POINT structure that contains the x- and y-coordinates of the cursor, in screen coordinates.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.MouseHookStruct.hwnd
member.summary: Handle to the window that will receive the mouse message corresponding to the mouse event.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.MouseHookStruct.wHitTestCode
member.summary: Specifies the hit-test value. For a list of hit-test values, see the description of the WM_NCHITTEST message.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.MouseHookStruct.dwExtraInfo
member.summary: Specifies extra information associated with the message.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.UpdateLayeredWindowFlags
member.summary: UpdateLayeredWindow API flags

member.name: F:Win32.User32.UpdateLayeredWindowFlags.Alpha
member.summary: Use pblend as the blend function. If the display mode is 256 colors or less, the effect of this value is the same as the effect of

member.name: F:Win32.User32.UpdateLayeredWindowFlags.ColorKey
member.summary: Use crKey as the transparency color.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.UpdateLayeredWindowFlags.Opaque
member.summary: Draw an opaque layered window.

Combination to be checked along with the hotkey

member.name: M:Win32.User32.User32API.SetWindowsHookEx(Win32.User32.HookType,Win32.User32.HookProc,System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: The SetWindowsHookEx function installs an application-defined hook procedure into a hook chain. You would install a hook procedure to monitor the system for certain types of events. These events are associated either with a specific thread or with all threads in the same desktop as the calling thread.
member.param: [in] Specifies the type of hook procedure to be installed. This parameter can be one of the following values.

[in] Pointer to the hook procedure. If the dwThreadId parameter is zero or specifies the identifier of a thread created by a different process, the lpfn parameter must point to a hook procedure in a dynamic-link library (DLL). Otherwise, lpfn can point to a hook procedure in the code associated with the current process.

[in] Handle to the DLL containing the hook procedure pointed to by the lpfn parameter. The hMod parameter must be set to NULL if the dwThreadId parameter specifies a thread created by the current process and if the hook procedure is within the code associated with the current process.

[in] Specifies the identifier of the thread with which the hook procedure is to be associated. If this parameter is zero, the hook procedure is associated with all existing threads running in the same desktop as the calling thread.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the hook procedure.
member.remarks: An error may occur if the hMod parameter is NULL and the dwThreadId parameter is zero or specifies the identifier of a thread created by another process. Calling the CallNextHookEx function to chain to the next hook procedure is optional, but it is highly recommended; otherwise, other applications that have installed hooks will not receive hook notifications and may behave incorrectly as a result. You should call CallNextHookEx unless you absolutely need to prevent the notification from being seen by other applications. Before terminating, an application must call the UnhookWindowsHookEx function to free system resources associated with the hook.

member.name: M:Win32.User32.User32API.UnhookWindowsHookEx(System.Int32)
member.summary: The UnhookWindowsHookEx function removes a hook procedure installed in a hook chain by the SetWindowsHookEx function.
member.param: [in] Handle to the hook to be removed. This parameter is a hook handle obtained by a previous call to SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
member.remarks: The hook procedure can be in the state of being called by another thread even after UnhookWindowsHookEx returns. If the hook procedure is not being called concurrently, the hook procedure is removed immediately before UnhookWindowsHookEx returns.

member.name: M:Win32.User32.User32API.CallNextHookEx(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The CallNextHookEx function passes the hook information to the next hook procedure in the current hook chain. A hook procedure can call this function either before or after processing the hook information.
member.param: [in] Specifies the hook code passed to the current hook procedure. The next hook procedure uses this code to determine how to process the hook information.
[in] Specifies the wParam value passed to the current hook procedure. The meaning of this parameter depends on the type of hook associated with the current hook chain.
[in] Specifies the lParam value passed to the current hook procedure. The meaning of this parameter depends on the type of hook associated with the current hook chain.
member.returns: This value is returned by the next hook procedure in the chain. The current hook procedure must also return this value. The meaning of the return value depends on the hook type. For more information, see the descriptions of the individual hook procedures.
member.remarks: Hook procedures are installed in chains for particular hook types. CallNextHookEx calls the next hook in the chain. Calling CallNextHookEx is optional, but it is highly recommended; otherwise, other applications that have installed hooks will not receive hook notifications and may behave incorrectly as a result. You should call CallNextHookEx unless you absolutely need to prevent the notification from being seen by other applications.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles
member.summary: Specifies the extended window style of the window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.AcceptFiles
member.summary: Specifies that a window created with this style accepts drag-drop files.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.ShowInTaskbar
member.summary: Forces a top-level window onto the taskbar when the window is visible.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.ClientEdge
member.summary: Specifies that a window has a border with a sunken edge.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.Composited
member.summary: Windows XP: Paints all descendants of a window in bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. For more information, see Remarks. This cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.ContextHelpBox
member.summary: Includes a question mark in the title bar of the window. When the user clicks the question mark, the cursor changes to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a child window, the child receives a WM_HELP message. The child window should pass the message to the parent window procedure, which should call the WinHelp function using the HELP_WM_HELP command. The Help application displays a pop-up window that typically contains help for the child window. WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP cannot be used with the WS_MAXIMIZEBOX or WS_MINIMIZEBOX styles.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.ControlParent
member.summary: The window itself contains child windows that should take part in dialog box navigation. If this style is specified, the dialog manager recurses into children of this window when performing navigation operations such as handling the TAB key, an arrow key, or a keyboard mnemonic.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.DialogModalFrame
member.summary: Creates a window that has a double border; the window can, optionally, be created with a title bar by specifying the WS_CAPTION style in the dwStyle parameter.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.Layered
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Creates a layered window. Note that this cannot be used for child windows. Also, this cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.LayoutRightToLeft
member.summary: Arabic and Hebrew versions of Windows 98/Me, Windows 2000/XP: Creates a window whose horizontal origin is on the right edge. Increasing horizontal values advance to the left.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.LeftAlignedProperties
member.summary: Creates a window that has generic left-aligned properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.LeftScrollBar
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading order alignment, the vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the left of the client area. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.LeftToRightReading
member.summary: The window text is displayed using left-to-right reading-order properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.MDIChild
member.summary: Creates a multiple-document interface (MDI) child window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.NoActivate
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: A top-level window created with this style does not become the foreground window when the user clicks it. The system does not bring this window to the foreground when the user minimizes or closes the foreground window. To activate the window, use the SetActiveWindow or SetForegroundWindow function. The window does not appear on the taskbar by default. To force the window to appear on the taskbar, use the WS_EX_APPWINDOW style.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.NoInheritLayout
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: A window created with this style does not pass its window layout to its child windows.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.NoParentNotify
member.summary: Specifies that a child window created with this style does not send the WM_PARENTNOTIFY message to its parent window when it is created or destroyed.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.OverlappedWindow
member.summary: Combines the WS_EX_CLIENTEDGE and WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE styles.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.PalleteWindow
member.summary: Combines the WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE, WS_EX_TOOLWINDOW, and WS_EX_TOPMOST styles.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.RightAlignedProperties
member.summary: The window has generic "right-aligned" properties. This depends on the window class. This style has an effect only if the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment; otherwise, the style is ignored. Using the WS_EX_RIGHT style for static or edit controls has the same effect as using the SS_RIGHT or ES_RIGHT style, respectively. Using this style with button controls has the same effect as using BS_RIGHT and BS_RIGHTBUTTON styles.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.RightScrollBar
member.summary: Vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the right of the client area. This is the default.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.RightToLeftReading
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment, the window text is displayed using right-to-left reading-order properties. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.StaticEdge
member.summary: Creates a window with a three-dimensional border style intended to be used for items that do not accept user input.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.ToolWindow
member.summary: Creates a tool window; that is, a window intended to be used as a floating toolbar. A tool window has a title bar that is shorter than a normal title bar, and the window title is drawn using a smaller font. A tool window does not appear in the taskbar or in the dialog that appears when the user presses ALT+TAB. If a tool window has a system menu, its icon is not displayed on the title bar. However, you can display the system menu by right-clicking or by typing ALT+SPACE.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.TopMost
member.summary: Specifies that a window created with this style should be placed above all non-topmost windows and should stay above them, even when the window is deactivated. To add or remove this style, use the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.Transparent
member.summary: Specifies that a window created with this style should not be painted until siblings beneath the window (that were created by the same thread) have been painted. The window appears transparent because the bits of underlying sibling windows have already been painted. To achieve transparency without these restrictions, use the SetWindowRgn function.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowExtendedStyles.WindowEdge
member.summary: Specifies that a window has a border with a raised edge.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues
member.summary: Attribute to change.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.ExtendedStyle
member.summary: Sets a new extended window style. For more information, see CreateWindowEx.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.Style
member.summary: Sets a new window style.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.WindowProcedure
member.summary: Sets a new address for the window procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.Handle
member.summary: Sets a new application instance handle.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.Id
member.summary: Sets a new identifier of the window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.UserData
member.summary: Sets the user data associated with the window. This data is intended for use by the application that created the window. Its value is initially zero.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.DialogProcedure
member.summary: Sets the new pointer to the dialog box procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.MessageResult
member.summary: Sets the return value of a message processed in the dialog box procedure.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowLongValues.User
member.summary: Sets new extra information that is private to the application, such as handles or pointers.

member.name: T:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags
member.summary: Specifies the window sizing and positioning flags. This parameter can be a combination of the following values

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.AsyncWindowPositioning
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.DeferErase
member.summary: Prevents generation of the WM_SYNCPAINT message.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.DrawFrame
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.FrameChanged
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the SetWindowLong function. Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.HideWindow
member.summary: Hides the window.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoActivate
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoCopyBits
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoMove
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores X and Y parameters).

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoOwnerZOrder
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoRedraw
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoRePosition
member.summary: Same as the SWP_NOOWNERZORDER flag.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoSendChanging
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoSize
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.NoZOrder
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:Win32.User32.WindowPositionSizeFlags.ShowWindow
member.summary: Displays the window.

member.summary: Represents a Win32 POINT structure

member.name: F:Win32.Point.x
member.summary: The X coordinate

member.name: F:Win32.Point.y
member.summary: The Y coordinate

member.name: M:Win32.Point.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the Point structure from two given coordinates

member.name: T:Win32.Rectangle
member.summary: Represents a Win32 RECT structure

member.summary: The X coordinate from the top left point

member.name: F:Win32.Rectangle.top
member.summary: The Y coordinate from the top left point

member.name: F:Win32.Rectangle.right
member.summary: The X coordinate from the bottom right point

member.name: F:Win32.Rectangle.bottom
member.summary: The Y coordinate from the bottom right point
